bibl.title: Letter from Michael E. Connor to Henry Rose Carter, May 3, 1922

div1.p: Connor recommends continued vigilance for at least six months after the last confirmed case of yellow fever. He discusses the political situation in Mexico, noting that the Tampico office is closing.

div1.head: Letter from Michael E. Connor to Henry Rose Carter, May 3, 1922

Tampico, Tamps., May 3- 1922
My dear Doctor Carter
div1.p:
Your letter and copy
of your article on y. f. in Peru were awaiting
me on my return from Merida.

I am pleased that you will write Juan
Martinez, it will please him, more so as
he knows of you and your work and
further are archeologist - interested in Maya
ruins have been receiving valuable informa-
tion from him, and strange as it may
seem, it has not occured to them to
even thank him. This is not quite true
of all, but nearly so.

I have sent in my final report on
Merida, stating that it is clear, but
advising the continuance of present intensive
efforts for at least six months after the last
confirmed case in the East coast region
Caldwell reported a case at San Cristobal

on March 20- He saw the
case, so he claims in the fifth
day - if it was a case, there some-
thing was wrong with the anti-
larvae measures supposed to have been carried
out in this region for nearly a year, wouldn't
you think so? Dr. White does not accept the
diagnosis easily - on his, White's, return from
New York I hope to go with him into this
area to study the conditions which make
hacienda impossible possible

Referring back to Merida - I did
not see a case of y. f. all the time I
was there, and the thought has ever been
with me that it spontaneously disappeared
with the exodus of soldiers and workers which
took place at the beginning of the home quier
crisis in 1918. This out ward movement had
practically ceased in the latter part of 1920,
and there will not be any movement
with Yucatan until the home quier market
improves and this is estimated for two years
from now, Campeche is dead - every boat

from there brings away 50 to
200 people. The world crisis here
has been so severe that the re-
venues of the State are insufficient to run
the government and there is talk that
the once proud state of Campeche will
slip back to the Status of a territory.

Tobacco is receiving the acid
test. The oil men have been flashing here
for some months now, Frontera and
Villahermosa especially and yet no
case, suspicious or confirmed, have
been am assessed, Dr. F. M. Evans “Fighting Bob,”
is at Frontera for an oil Company-.

We are closing out in Tampico
on July 1st.

With sincere good wishes to Miss Laura
and the kindest personal regards to your-
self, I remain your friend and
well wisher
